facts.text: Government of India devised schemes for rehabilitation of refugees, including sale of box-type tenements in West Patel Nagar to displaced persons registered before August 15, 1948, gainfully employed, and who had been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

Procedure: Eligible applicants submit form, deposit sale price after prima facie eligibility, produce proof later; list prepared, excess refunded; final list pays ground rent; allotment by drawing lots.
Jagan Nath registered as refugee on December 31, 1947.
Jagan Nath applied in prescribed form, deposited Rs. 5,600 sale price after prima facie eligibility, deposited ground rent, informed of allotment of two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house.
Allotment by drawing lots on February 15, 1952 at 3 p.m., house No. 35 West Patel Nagar allotted to Jagan Nath.
On May 10, 1952, Accommodation Officer removed Jagan Nath's family and belongings to house No. 35 in his absence, entering possession.
Jagan Nath evicted on September 27, 1952 by warrant dated September 11, 1952 under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.
Possession given to Sohan Lal on October 3, 1952.
Sohan Lal, displaced person, applied February 27, 1952, deposited Rs. 5,600, complied with conditions, allotted house No. 35 on July 31, 1952.
Sohan Lal in possession since October 3, 1952.
Jagan Nath ineligible as allotted agricultural land in Hissar district prior to application.
No letter of allotment issued to Jagan Nath; informed property could not be allotted due to ineligibility.
Jagan Nath filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court, allowed, ordering Union of India and Sohan Lal to restore possession of house No. 35.
Sohan Lal obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether writ under Art. 226 appropriate where serious factual disputes on title exist, requiring declaration of title and restoration of possession.
Whether mandamus can issue against private individual (Sohan Lal) in possession without evidence of collusion with Union of India.
Whether Jagan Nath acquired title or rights in property despite no letter of allotment and subsequent discovery of ineligibility.
Legality of Jagan Nath's eviction without compliance with s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Serious dispute on facts and whether Jagan Nath acquired title; writ proceedings inappropriate as decision would declare title and order restoration; proper remedy is civil suit.
Mandamus cannot issue against private individual; Sohan Lal in lawful possession, no evidence or finding of collusion with Union of India.

respondent_arguments.text: Entered possession not as trespasser but inducted by Accommodation Officer; evicted illegally without notice under s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950; Union of India and Sohan Lal ordered to restore possession.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950 (Act No. XXVII of 1950)

court_reasoning.text: Will not enquire into merits of rival title claims; questions of fact and law disputed, appropriate for civil court suit, not Art. 226 writ proceedings which cannot declare title and decree possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Writ court should not enter field of title investigation.

court_reasoning.text: Eviction contravened s. 3 Public Premises Eviction Act, illegal; mandamus could issue against Union of India if property still in its possession, but property with appellant.
No evidence or finding of collusion between Union of India and appellant; mandamus does not issue against private individual without public duty or collusion; appellant entered bona fide.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandamus against person for public duty; analogy to election cases where quo warranto needed.

court_reasoning.text: Questions like rights acquired by Jagan Nath, whether possession under allotment or misapprehension, appellant's legal right, to be decided in civil suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All disputed issues require civil court adjudication.

holdings.text: High Court erred in allowing Art. 226 petition and ordering restoration against Union of India and private individual without resolving title disputes or finding collusion.
Mandamus does not lie against bona fide possessor without collusion or knowledge of illegal eviction.

precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction.

precedents_cited.case_name: G. Kistareddy v. Commr. of City Police, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohinder Singh v. State of Pepsu
precedents_cited.relevance: Support for restoration after illegal eviction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wazir Chand v. The State of Himachal Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations supporting restoration after illegal eviction.

precedents_cited.citation: 1855 25 L.J.Q.B. 61; Regina v. Chester, Mayor, etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mandamus not granted if office/property in bona fide possession; quo warranto or other proceedings needed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition filed; court held inappropriate for title disputes.

statutes_cited.name: Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Required notice before eviction; non-compliance made eviction illegal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside; Jagan Nath's Art. 226 petition not maintainable due to title disputes requiring civil suit; no mandamus against appellant.

key_quotes.text: We do number propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Declines to resolve factual title disputes in writ proceedings.

key_quotes.text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does number issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is number made against a private individual.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of mandamus to public duties, not private possessors.

key_quotes.text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in companytravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges illegality of eviction but denies writ remedy.
